metadata.title: Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen over Pd/HZSM-5 catalysts: Effect of Brönsted acidity

Graphical abstract In the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen over Pd/HZSM-5 catalysts, yield for hydrogen peroxide increased with increasing B/L ratio of the catalysts. Highlights ► Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen was conducted. ► Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts with different Si/Al molar ratio (X) were used. ► Yield for hydrogen peroxide increased with increasing B/L ratio of the catalyst. ► Yield for hydrogen peroxide increased with increasing Brönsted acidity of the catalyst. Palladium catalysts supported on HZSM-5 (Pd/HZSM-5-X (X =15, 30, 75, 100, and 150)) were prepared with a variation of Si/Al molar ratio (X), and they were applied to the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen. Conversion of hydrogen over Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts showed no great difference, while selectivity for hydrogen peroxide over the catalysts exhibited a volcano-shaped curve with respect to Si/Al molar ratio. As a consequence, yield for hydrogen peroxide over the catalysts showed a volcano-shaped curve with respect to Si/Al molar ratio. Yield for hydrogen peroxide over Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts was closely related to the Brönsted acidity/Lewis acidity (B/L) ratio of the catalysts. Yield for hydrogen peroxide increased with increasing B/L ratio of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts. This indicates that Brönsted acid sites of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts played an important role for enhancing the catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide. Furthermore, yield for hydrogen peroxide increased with increasing Brönsted acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts. Among the catalysts tested, Pd/HZSM-5-30 catalyst with the largest Brönsted acidity showed the highest yield for hydrogen peroxide. Therefore, it is concluded that Brönsted acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts served as an important factor determining the catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide. Keywords Hydrogen peroxide Palladium HZSM-5 Si/Al molar ratio Brönsted acidity 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) has been used as a clean and strong oxidant in various areas such as pulp industry, textile industry, wastewater treatment, and green chemical synthesis [1–3]. Hydrogen peroxide is mostly produced through the anthraquinone auto-oxidation process [1,2]. However, this process uses toxic compounds and requires energy intensive steps for separation and purification of hydrogen peroxide [1,2]. Therefore, direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen (H2) and oxygen (O2) has attracted much attention as an economical and environmentally benign process [4–14]. It has been reported that several undesired reactions occur together with selective oxidation of hydrogen to hydrogen peroxide (H2 +O2 →H2O2) in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen [1,2]. These undesired reactions include formation of water (H2 +0.5O2 →H2O), decomposition of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2 →H2O+0.5O2), and hydrogenation of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2 +H2 →2H2O) [1,2]. For this reason, selectivity for hydrogen peroxide in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide is limited. Therefore, many attempts have been made to enhance the selectivity for hydrogen peroxide in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide [6–11]. Various noble metals such as palladium [4–11], palladium–gold [12,13], and palladium–platinum [14] have been used as catalysts in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen. Among these catalysts, palladium is known to be the most efficient catalyst in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide [4–11]. Palladium catalyst has been supported on various materials for effective dispersion of active metal component [4,5]. Acids and halides have been used as additives to enhance the selectivity for hydrogen peroxide in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide [1,2,6–11]. It has been reported that acid additives inhibit the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide and halide additives prevent the formation of water [1,2,11,15]. However, acid additives cause the corrosion of reactor and the dissolution of active metal component from the supported catalyst. Therefore, solid acid supports have been investigated as an alternate acid source in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide [16–20]. It has been reported that solid acid supports such as SO3H-functionalized mesoporous silicas [16], insoluble heteropolyacids [17,18], and insoluble heteropolyacid-supported mesoporous silicas [19,20] efficiently served as an alternate acid source in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen. It has also been reported that acidity of the catalysts played a crucial role in determining the catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide [16,17,19,20]. However, no work has been done to examine the effect of nature of acid sites on the catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide. HZSM-5 is the most useful zeolite in various chemical processes because it has a strong acid property and a unique three dimensional pore structure [21,22]. It is known that HZSM-5 can be synthesized to have a wide range of Si/Al molar ratio. It has been reported that acid property of HZSM-5 is strongly affected by Si/Al molar ratio [21,22]. In this work, a series of HZSM-5 with different Si/Al molar ratio were prepared for use as a solid acid support for palladium catalyst. Palladium catalysts supported on HZSM-5 (Pd/HZSM-5) were then applied to the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen. The effect of Si/Al molar ratio on the catalytic performance of Pd/HZSM-5 catalysts in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide was examined. The effect of nature of acid sites of Pd/HZSM-5 catalysts was also investigated. Correlations between acid property and catalytic performance of Pd/HZSM-5 catalysts were then established and discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of HZSM-5 were prepared by a hydrothermal synthesis method with a variation of Si/Al molar ratio. Palladium catalyst supported on HZSM-5 (Pd/HZSM-5) was then prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation method. Typical procedures for the preparation of Pd/HZSM-5 catalyst are as follows. 0.48g of sodium hydroxide (NaOH, Sigma–Aldrich) was dissolved in 40ml of distilled water at 60°C. 0.68g of tetrapropylammonium bromide (TPABr, Sigma–Aldrich) and 19.1ml of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, Sigma–Aldrich) were added into the solution under vigorous stirring, and the mixture was then stirred at 60°C until a homogeneous solution was obtained. An appropriate amount of sodium aluminate (NaAlO2, Sigma–Aldrich) was separately dissolved in 14.0ml of distilled water, and it was slowly added into the mixture. The resulting mixture was stirred at 60°C for 3h, and then it was crystallized in an autoclave at 160°C for 60h. After filtering and washing a solid product with distilled water, the solid product was dried overnight at 100°C and calcined at 550°C for 5h to obtain Na-ZSM-5. Na-ZSM-5 was then ion-exchanged with 1.0M aqueous solution of ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3, Sigma–Aldrich) at 80°C for 3h. After filtering and washing a solid with distilled water, the solid was dried overnight at 100°C and finally calcined at 550°C for 5h to obtain HZSM-5. Palladium nitrate (Pd(NO3)2, Sigma–Aldrich) was supported on HZSM-5. The palladium loading was fixed at 0.5wt%. The impregnated solid was dried overnight at 80°C and calcined at 500°C for 3h. The calcined catalyst was reduced at 200°C for 2h with a mixed stream of hydrogen (5ml/min) and nitrogen (20ml/min) to yield Pd/HZSM-5 catalyst. Si/Al molar ratio of Pd/HZSM-5 catalysts was adjusted to be 15, 30, 75, 100, and 150. Pd/HZSM-5 catalysts were denoted as Pd/HZSM-5-X (X =15, 30, 75, 100, and 150), where X represented the Si/Al molar ratio. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Si/Al molar ratio and palladium content in the catalysts were measured by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) analysis (Shimadzu, ICPS-7500). Hydrogen chemisorption experiment (BEL Japan, BELCAT-B) was conducted to examine the palladium dispersion of the catalyst. Prior to the chemisorption measurement, 0.05g of each catalyst was reduced at 200°C for 2h with a mixed stream of hydrogen (2.5ml/min) and argon (47.5ml/min), and subsequently, it was purged at 200°C for 40min under a flow of argon (50ml/min). After cooling the catalyst to 50°C, the amount of hydrogen uptake was measured by periodically injecting diluted hydrogen (5mol% hydrogen and 95mol% argon) into the catalyst. Palladium dispersion was calculated by assuming that one hydrogen atom occupies one surface palladium atom. X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the catalyst was confirmed by XRD measurement (Rigaku, D-Max2500-PC) using Cu Kα radiation operated at 50kV and 100mA. Surface area of the catalyst was measured from nitrogen adsorption–desorption experiment (Micromeritics, ASAP 2010). Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiment (BEL Japan, BELCAT-B) was carried out in order to measure the acidity of the catalyst. 0.05g of each catalyst charged into the TPD apparatus was pretreated at 200°C for 1h with a stream of helium (50ml/min). A mixed stream of ammonia (2.5ml/min) and helium (47.5ml/min) was then introduced into the reactor at 35°C for 30min in order to saturate acid sites of the catalyst with ammonia. Physisorbed ammonia was removed at 100°C for 1h under a flow of helium (50ml/min). After cooling the catalyst, furnace temperature was increased from 35°C to 900°C at a heating rate of 5°C/min under a flow of helium (30ml/min). Desorbed ammonia was detected using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The nature of acid sites of the catalyst was examined by in situ Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy (ThermoFisher Scientific, Nicolet 6700) of adsorbed pyridine. FT-IR spectrometer was equipped with a diffuse reflectance accessory. Prior to the measurement, 10mg of each catalyst was mixed with 40mg of potassium bromide (KBr, Sigma–Aldrich) [23]. The solid mixture was poured into a sample cup and pretreated at 200°C for 1h with a stream of helium (40ml/min). After cooling the catalyst to 50°C, pyridine vapor was injected under a flow of helium (40ml/min) until the acid sites were saturated with pyridine. Physisorbed pyridine was removed by evacuating the catalyst sample at 100°C for 1h. After cooling the catalyst sample, furnace temperature was increased from room temperature to 200°C at a heating rate of 5°C/min under a flow of helium (40ml/min). IR spectrum was recorded at 100°C in the spectral range of 1675–1325cm−1 using KBr background. 2.3 Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen was carried out in an autoclave reactor in the absence of acid additive. 80ml of methanol (Sigma–Aldrich) and 6.32mg of sodium bromide (NaBr, Sigma–Aldrich) were charged into the reactor. 1g of each catalyst was then added into the reactor. Hydrogen (25mol% hydrogen and 75mol% nitrogen) and oxygen (50mol% oxygen and 50mol% nitrogen) were bubbled through the reaction medium under vigorous stirring (1000rpm). Molar ratio of hydrogen to oxygen in the feed stream was fixed at 0.4, and total feed rate was maintained at 44ml/min. Catalytic reaction was carried out at 28°C and 10atm for 6h. In this reaction, hydrogen and oxygen were diluted with nitrogen, and an autoclave reactor was equipped with a flashback arrestor as well as a safety valve in order to solve the safety problem. Unreacted hydrogen was analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Younglin, ACME 6000) equipped with a TCD and a packed column (Supelco, Molecular Sieve 5A, 80/100 mesh, 1.8m×1/8in., 2.1mm). Concentration of hydrogen peroxide was determined by an iodometric titration method [24]. Conversion of hydrogen and selectivity for hydrogen peroxide were calculated according to the following equations. Yield for hydrogen peroxide was calculated by multiplying conversion of hydrogen and selectivity for hydrogen peroxide: Conversion of hydrogen = moles of hydrogen reacted moles of hydrogen supplied Selectivity for hydrogen peroxide = moles of hydrogen peroxide formed moles of hydrogen reacted In order to see any possible formation of methanol oxidation products such as carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide, the gaseous reaction mixture was analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Younglin, ACME 6000) equipped with a TCD and a packed column (Supelco, Molecular Sieve 5A, 80/100 mesh, 1.8m×1/8 in., 2.1mm). To see any formation of HCHO, furthermore, the reaction solvent was analyzed after the reaction using a gas chromatograph (Younglin, ACME 6000) equipped with a TCD and a packed column (Supelco, Porapak T, 80/100 mesh, 1.8m×1/8 in., 2.1mm). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Formation of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts Si/Al molar ratio of Pd/HZSM-5-X (X =15, 30, 75, 100, and 150) catalysts determined by ICP-AES analysis is listed in Table 1 . The measured Si/Al molar ratio of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts was similar to the theoretical value. Palladium content of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts determined by ICP-AES analysis is also listed in Table 1. Palladium content of the catalysts was in good agreement with the designed value. These results imply that Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts were successfully prepared as attempted in this work. Palladium dispersion of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts measured by hydrogen chemisorption experiments is also summarized in Table 1. Palladium dispersion of the catalysts was in the range of 6.5–32.9%. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of Pd/HZSM-5-X (X =15, 30, 75, 100, and 150) catalysts. XRD patterns of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts were in good agreement with those reported in the previous work [21]. This indicates that all the Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts exhibit a typical MFI structure, which is the intrinsic crystalline structure of HZSM-5 [21]. It was observed that XRD patterns of the catalysts were almost identical regardless of different Si/Al molar ratio. Once again, this implies that all the catalysts were successfully prepared in this work. BET surface area of Pd/HZSM-5-X (X =15, 30, 75, 100, and 150) catalysts determined by nitrogen adsorption–desorption experiment is listed in Table 2 . All the Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts showed almost the same BET surface area with no significant difference. BET surface area of the catalysts was similar to the value in literatures [21,22]. This result also supports that Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts were successfully prepared. 3.2 Catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide Fig. 2 shows the catalytic performance of Pd/HZSM-5-X (X =15, 30, 75, 100, and 150) catalysts in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen, plotted as a function of Si/Al molar ratio (X). Conversion of hydrogen over Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts showed no great difference, while selectivity for hydrogen peroxide over the catalysts exhibited a volcano-shaped curve with respect to Si/Al molar ratio. As a consequence, yield for hydrogen peroxide over the catalysts showed a volcano-shaped curve with respect to Si/Al molar ratio. Final concentration of hydrogen peroxide after a 6-h reaction also showed a volcano-shaped curve with respect to Si/Al molar ratio. Among the catalysts tested, Pd/HZSM-5-30 catalyst showed the best catalytic performance in terms of selectivity for hydrogen peroxide, yield for hydrogen peroxide, and final concentration of hydrogen peroxide. It is noteworthy that no noticeable dissolution of palladium species was observed during the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide, as listed in Table 1. This indicates that all the catalysts were stable during the reaction. It was also observed that methanol oxidation products such as carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, and formaldehyde were not detected during the reaction. This result also implies that the reaction solvent was completely stable under the reaction conditions. Fig. 3 shows the catalytic performance of Pd/HZSM-5-30 catalyst in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen with reaction time. Conversion of hydrogen was constant during a 6-h reaction, while selectivity for hydrogen peroxide and yield for hydrogen peroxide increased with increasing reaction time. Concentration of hydrogen peroxide continuously increased with increasing reaction time. These results indicate that the catalyst deactivation did not occur during the reaction. 3.3 Effect of acid additive on the catalytic performance Fig. 4 shows the catalytic performance of Pd/HZSM-5-30 catalyst in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen at different concentrations of H3PO4. 0.645ml of 1M H3PO4 solution was added to the reaction medium in order to make the concentration of H3PO4 became 1000ppm. Catalytic performance of the catalyst in the presence of H3PO4 was similar to that in the absence of H3PO4. This indicates that H3PO4 additive had no effect on the catalytic performance of Pd/HZSM-5-30 catalyst. Fig. 5 shows the catalytic performance of Pd/HZSM-5-∞ (palladium catalyst supported on aluminum-free HZSM-5) in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen at different concentrations of H3PO4. Conversion of hydrogen in the presence of H3PO4 was almost identical to that in the absence of H3PO4, while selectivity for hydrogen peroxide in the presence of H3PO4 was higher than that in the absence of H3PO4. Consequently, yield for hydrogen peroxide in the presence of H3PO4 was considerably higher than that in the absence of H3PO4. Final concentration of hydrogen peroxide in the presence of H3PO4 after a 6-h reaction was also higher than that in the absence of H3PO4. This is in good agreement with the fact that acid additives enhanced the selectivity for hydrogen peroxide [1,2,6–11]. Direct comparison of Fig. 4 and Fig. 5 showed that the catalytic performance of Pd/HZSM-5-30 catalyst was less sensitive to the concentration of H3PO4 than that of Pd/HZSM-5-∞. This implies that HZSM-5 efficiently served as an acid source in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen. 3.4 Acid property of the catalysts Fig. 6 shows the NH3-TPD profiles of Pd/HZSM-5-X (X =15, 30, 75, 100, and 150) catalysts. Total acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts calculated from the peak area is summarized in Table 3 . Total acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts increased with decreasing Si/Al molar ratio (X). Among the catalysts, Pd/HZSM-5-15 showed the largest total acidity. It is known that acid sites are created by incorporating Al into the framework of HZSM-5 [25,26]. Therefore, it can be inferred that total acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts increased with increasing the amount of Al incorporated into the framework of HZSM-5. Experimental observations (Table 3 and Fig. 2) revealed that the catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen was not directly correlated with the total acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X (X =15, 30, 75, 100, and 150) catalysts. It is known that acid additives enhance the selectivity for hydrogen peroxide because they prevent the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide [1,2,11,15]. It has also been reported that the dissociation of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2 ⇔HO2 − +H+) is suppressed when hydrogen peroxide is surrounded by protons (H+ ions) of acid additives [2]. This implies that only Brönsted acid sites of the catalysts are needed for enhancing the selectivity for hydrogen peroxide. However, Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts retained both Brönsted and Lewis acid sites. In this work, therefore, total acidity itself of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts measured by NH3-TPD experiment did not serve as a crucial factor determining the catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide. In order to elucidate the different catalytic performances of Pd/HZSM-5-X (X =15, 30, 75, 100, and 150) catalysts, in situ FT-IR spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine was conducted to examine the nature of acid sites of the catalysts. Fig. 7 shows the FT-IR spectra of pyridine adsorbed on Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts. IR bands were assigned according to the literatures [27–29]. All the Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts showed a broad band at around 1640cm−1, which was attributed to bending vibration of hydroxyl group of water molecules adsorbed on the window of IR cell [29,30]. Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts exhibited IR bands due to hydrogen bonded pyridine (1440 and 1595cm−1), Lewis acid bound pyridine (1450, 1490, and 1580cm−1), and Brönsted acid bound pyridinium ion (1490 and 1545cm−1) [27–29]. Brönsted acidity and Lewis acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts were quantitatively measured according to the method reported in the literature [31]. The integrated molar extinction coefficients of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites were chosen to be 1.67 and 2.22cm/μmol, respectively. The amounts of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites of the catalysts were calculated from the IR band area at 1545 and 1450cm−1, according to the follow equations: Bröensted acid site amount = I A ( B ) × π × R 2 1.67 × W Lewis acid site amount = I A ( L ) × π × R 2 2.22 × W IA(B) is the integrated absorbance of Brönsted acid site (cm−1), IA(L) is the integrated absorbance of Lewis acid site (cm−1), R is the inner radius of sample cup (cm) and W is the weight of catalyst (mg). The ratio of Brönsted acidity to Lewis acidity (B/L ratio) of Pd/HZSM-5-X (X =15, 30, 75, 100, and 150) catalysts is summarized in Table 3. It is interesting to note that B/L ratio of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts showed a volcano-shaped trend with respect to Si/Al molar ratio (X). Among the catalysts, Pd/HZSM-5-30 showed the highest B/L ratio. It is known that Brönsted acid site of HZSM-5 is attributed to bridging hydroxyl group in Si–OH–Al linkage [25,26]. It has also been reported that Lewis acid site of HZSM-5 is formed on the Al in hydroxoaluminum complex [25]. Therefore, it can be inferred that B/L ratio of the catalysts decreased due to the increase of the amount of Lewis acid site, because the formation of hydroxoaluminum complex increased when a large amount of Al was incorporated into the framework of HZSM-5. 3.5 Effect of nature of acid sites on the catalytic performance Fig. 8 shows the correlation between yield for hydrogen peroxide and B/L ratio of Pd/HZSM-5-X (X =15, 30, 75, 100, and 150) catalysts. The correlation clearly shows that yield for hydrogen peroxide over Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts was closely related to the B/L ratio of the catalysts. Yield for hydrogen peroxide increased with increasing B/L ratio of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalyst. Among the catalysts tested, Pd/HZSM-5-30 catalyst with the highest B/L ratio showed the highest yield for hydrogen peroxide. This indicates that Brönsted acid sites of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts played an important role for enhancing the catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen. This result was also well consistent with the fact that protons of acid additives increased the selectivity for hydrogen peroxide [1,2]. In order to correlate the catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen with the Brönsted acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X (X =15, 30, 75, 100, and 150) catalysts, Brönsted acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts was obtained from total acidity (measured by NH3-TPD experiment) and ratio of Brönsted acidity to total acidity (measured by FT-IR spectroscopy) (Table 3). Fig. 9 shows the correlation between yield for hydrogen peroxide and Brönsted acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts. Yield for hydrogen peroxide increased with increasing Brönsted acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalyst. Among the catalysts tested, Pd/HZSM-5-30 catalyst with the largest Brönsted acidity showed the highest yield for hydrogen peroxide. This result implies that Brönsted acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts is an important factor determining the catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide. 4 Conclusions A series of HZSM-5 were prepared with a variation of Si/Al molar ratio (X) for use as a solid acid support for palladium catalyst. Palladium catalysts supported on HZSM-5 (Pd/HZSM-5-X (X =15, 30, 75, 100, and 150)) were then applied to the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen. Conversion of hydrogen over Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts showed no great difference, while selectivity for hydrogen peroxide over the catalysts exhibited a volcano-shaped curve with respect to Si/Al molar ratio. Consequently, yield for hydrogen peroxide over the catalysts showed a volcano-shaped curve with respect to Si/Al molar ratio. The catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide was not correlated with the total acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts, because Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts had both Brönsted and Lewis acid sites. On the other hand, yield for hydrogen peroxide over Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts was closely related to the B/L ratio of the catalysts. Yield for hydrogen peroxide increased with increasing B/L ratio of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts. Furthermore, yield for hydrogen peroxide increased with increasing Brönsted acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalyst. Among the catalysts tested, Pd/HZSM-5-30 catalyst with the largest Brönsted acidity showed the highest yield for hydrogen peroxide. These results indicate that Brönsted acid sites of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts played a crucial role for enhancing the catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide. Thus, Brönsted acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts served as an important factor determining the catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide. coredata.dc:description: Palladium catalysts supported on HZSM-5 (Pd/HZSM-5-X (X =15, 30, 75, 100, and 150)) were prepared with a variation of Si/Al molar ratio (X), and they were applied to the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen. Conversion of hydrogen over Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts showed no great difference, while selectivity for hydrogen peroxide over the catalysts exhibited a volcano-shaped curve with respect to Si/Al molar ratio. As a consequence, yield for hydrogen peroxide over the catalysts showed a volcano-shaped curve with respect to Si/Al molar ratio. Yield for hydrogen peroxide over Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts was closely related to the Brönsted acidity/Lewis acidity (B/L) ratio of the catalysts. Yield for hydrogen peroxide increased with increasing B/L ratio of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts. This indicates that Brönsted acid sites of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts played an important role for enhancing the catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide. Furthermore, yield for hydrogen peroxide increased with increasing Brönsted acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts. Among the catalysts tested, Pd/HZSM-5-30 catalyst with the largest Brönsted acidity showed the highest yield for hydrogen peroxide. Therefore, it is concluded that Brönsted acidity of Pd/HZSM-5-X catalysts served as an important factor determining the catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide.
coredata.dc:title: Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen over Pd/HZSM-5 catalysts: Effect of Brönsted acidity
